predicted_summary: secondary metal theft prevention act of 2009 - Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to investigate and enforce the theft of metal components in transportation, electrical, and telecommunications networks.Secondary Metal Recycling Act of 2001 - Establishes the Safety Sense Act of the Congress to require the secondary metal recycling industry to develop and improve countermeasures to combat the theft and sale of stolen metal.Secondary Metal Theft Act of 2001 - Makes it unlawful for a secondary metal recycling agent to purchase secondary metal that is: (1) marked with name, logo, or initials of a railroad, an electric, gas, or water company, or a public utility or that has been altered to remove, conceal, or obliterate such a name or logo or initials through burning or cutting of wire sheathing or other means; and (2) to establish a system to document secondary metal transactions between sellers and buyers while addressing the growing problem of secondary metal theft.Requires a secondary metal recycling agent to maintain a written or electronic record of each secondary metal purchase.Requires: (1) a secondary metal recycling agent to maintain any record required by this Act with respect to the second or a subsequent purchase of secondary metal from the same person; (2) recording any information for the transaction that is different from the existing record for that person; and (3) maintaining any record for not less than two years.Requires a secondary metal recycling agent to make payment by check for purchases of secondary metal in excess of $75 from a governmental or commercial supplier of primary metal.Requires: (1) a secondary metal recycling agency or the agent, employee, or representative of such agency to: (2) disclose the identity of any person who purchases secondary metal without the seller's consent; and (3) make such agency liable for unauthorized access to or disclosure of such information.Authorizes a State to bring a civil action on behalf of its residents to enforce the provisions of this Act whenever the Attorney General of the State has reason to believe that the interests of the residents of that State have been or are being threatened or adversely affected by this Act or a regulation under this Act.Directs the Attorney General to provide to the Federal Trade Commission a written notice of action against a secondary metal recycling agent for a violation of this Act or any regulation, and a copy of the complaint for the action. Sets forth procedural requirements for bringing such action.Secondary Metal Recycling Act - Directs any person engaged in the business of purchasing secondary metal for reuse or recycling to enter into the business without regard to whether that person is engaged in any business of recycling or processing the purchased metal.Requires this Act to take effect six months after the date of enactment.
summary:
Secondary Metal Theft Prevention Act of 2009 - Expresses the sense of Congress that government agencies should work with representatives of the secondary metal recycling industry to combat the theft and sale of stolen secondary metal. Defines "secondary metal" as: (1) wire or cable commonly used by communications and electrical utilities; and (2) copper, aluminum, or other metal (including when combined with other materials) that is valuable for recycling or reuse as raw metal.

Makes it unlawful to sell certain secondary metal unless the seller documents ownership and maintains written or electronic records of each secondary metal purchase. Includes within the prohibition: (1) secondary metal that is marked with the name, logo, or initials of a railroad, a utility company, or a state or local government; (2) highway or street poles, fixtures, rails, or signs; (3) unused or undamaged building construction or utility material; (4) historical markers or grave markers; and (5) large bulk containers for beer. Prohibits cash purchases of secondary metal in excess of $75 or small multiple cash purchases within a 48-hour period. Requires purchasers of secondary metal in excess of $75 to pay by check.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general to enforce this Act. Imposes a civil penalty for violations.

Declares that this Act does not preempt any state or local law regulating the sale or purchase of secondary metal.

predicted_summary: Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003 - Amends Public Law 93-100 to allow the owner of any deposited or account which is a deposit or account on which interest or dividends are paid to make such a sum to another account of the owner in the same institution.Requires the Federal Reserve Bank to: (1) make payments to the depository institution at least once each calendar quarter at a rate not to exceed the general interest rate; and (2) ensure that such earnings are paid to the institution through a specified mechanism.Amends the Federal Reserve Act to: (1) extend the Federal reserve board's flexibility in setting reserve requirements for member banks; (2) increase federal reserve flexibility; and (3) extend through reserves authorized by the Board to any branch or agency of a foreign bank (as defined in the International Monetary Fund Act of 1978).Amends the Federal Reserve Act to: (1) make additional transfers to the Treasury for deposit in the General Fund of the Treasury; and (2) extend the term of such transfers through FY 2007 to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007.Authorizes any Federal reserve bank to replenish its surplus fund by transferring certain amounts of its paid-in capital and surplus to the Secretary of the Treasury for deposit in the General Fund.
summary: Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003 - Amends Federal law to authorize interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month (or any greater number the Federal Reserve Board may determine) to another account of the owner in the same institution.Authorizes the payment of interest by a Federal reserve bank at least quarterly on balances maintained there on behalf of a depository institution.Amends the Federal Reserve Act to revise the ratio of reserves a depository institution must maintain against its transaction accounts, permitting a ratio of zero.Directs the Federal Reserve banks in FY 2003 through 2007 to transfer to the Board for transfer to the Secretary of the Treasury, for deposit in the general fund, additional surplus funds equal to the net cost of their interest payments to depository institutions.

predicted_summary: Maritime Administration Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001 - Amends the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to authorize appropriations for the use of the Department of Transportation for the Maritime Administration. Authorizes appropriations for: (1) expenses necessary for operations and training activities; and (2) administrative expenses related to loan guarantee commitments.Directs the Department of the Coast Guard to ensure that vessels built in foreign countries are certified as U.S.-built if: (1) the vessel is delivered from a foreign shipyard before the date of enactment of the Maritime Administration authorization Act for fiscal year 2001; or (2) the effective date of the Oecd shipbuilding trade agreement (CTA). Limits such documentation to a newly constructed drybulk or breakbulk vessel over 7,500 deadweight tons that has been contracted for or delivered before the earlier of such date.Directs the Secretary of State to initiate discussions in all appropriate international forums in order to establish an international standard for the scrapping of vessels.Directs the Secretary of Transportation to develop a ship scrapping program within 9 months after the date of this Act for the scrapping of obsolete National Defense Reserve Fleet vessels.Requires: (1) a program through qualified scrapping facilities to scrap vessels that pose a serious threat to the environment or to the U.S. economy; (2) a report by the Department of Defense's interagency panel on ship scrapping; and (3) the selection of a scrapping facility based on a best value basis.Amends the National Maritime Heritage Act of 1994 (NMSHEA) to: (1) extend the program through 2006; (2) require the Secretary to proceed with the cancellation of all vessels in the National Defense Reserve Fleet except the export challenger; (3) export commerce; and (4) provide specified export channels for export commerce.Santa Barbara County Historical Society Annual Report    This year, the Santa Barbara Historical Society will present a biennial report on Santa Barbara, California, and the Pacific Ocean.Amends the Merchant Marine Act to require the Department of Transportation, in coordination with the Secretary of the Navy, to report annually on the progress of the ship scrapping program developed under this Act and on the status of any other scrapping of government-owned vessels. Authorizes the Secretary to make a grant to an institute designated under the Maritime and Maritime Intermodal Research Act as if it were a university transportation center.Maritime Research and Technology Development Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to conduct a study of maritime research and technology development.Directs the Secretary to convey to the Society, Inc., a corporation established under the laws of the State of Connecticut that is located in Bridgeport, Connecticut.Requires the Secretary to convey the vessel if: (1) the corporation agrees to use the vessel for the purpose of a monument to the accomplishments of members of the Armed Forces of the United States, civilians, scientists, and diplomats in exploration of the Arctic and the Antarctic; (2) the Corporation provides sufficient evidence to the Secretary that it has available for use to restore the vessel, in the form of cash, liquid assets, or a written loan commitment; (3) the Secretary agrees to hold the government harmless for any claims arising from use of the vessel after the conveyance; and (4) the government agrees to make the vessel available to the government if the Secretary requires use of it if it requires use by the Secretary for war or national emergency.Requires the Secretary to: (1) deliver the vessel at the place where the vessel is located on the date of the conveyance; (2) in its condition on that date; and (3) at no cost to the United States government.Authorizes appropriations for fiscal year 2001 for certain maritime programs of the Department of Transportation.
summary:
(Sec. 3) Amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 to declare that certain restrictions concerning a vessel built in a foreign country shall not apply to a newly constructed drybulk or breakbulk vessel over 7,500 deadweight tons that has been delivered from a foreign shipyard or contracted for construction in a foreign shipyard before the earlier of two specified dates. Deems U.S.-built any vessel timely contracted for or delivered and documented under U.S. law, if certain conditions are met.
(Sec. 4) Directs the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of Transportation, to initiate discussions in all appropriate international forums to establish an international standard for the scrapping of vessels in a safe and environmentally sound manner.
Directs the Secretary of Transportation to develop, and report to specified congressional committees on, a program for the scrapping of obsolete National Defense Reserve Fleet Vessels.
Amends the National Maritime Heritage Act of 1994 to extend, through September 30, 2006, the authority of the Secretary to dispose of certain vessels in the National Defense Reserve Fleet. Requires that such vessels be disposed of in the most cost effective manner to the United States, taking into account the need for disposal, the environment, and safety concerns.
Amends Federal law to authorize the expenditure of funds from the National Defense Sealift Fund for costs related to the scrapping of National Defense Reserve Fleet vessels.
Names vessels in the National Defense Reserve Fleet that may be scrapped in the United States or a foreign country.
(Sec. 5) Requires the Maritime Administration (in its annual report to Congress and its estimated annual budget) to state separately the amount, source, intended use, and nature of any funds (other than funds appropriated to the Administration or to the Secretary for use by the Administration) administered, or subject to oversight, by the Administration.
(Sec. 6) Amends Federal maritime law to authorize the Secretary of Transportation to make a grant to a National Maritime Enhancement Institute for maritime and maritime intermodal research as if the Institute were a university transportation center.
(Sec. 7) Directs the Secretary to study maritime research and technology development, and report the results, including any recommendations, to Congress. Authorizes appropriations.
(Sec. 8) Authorizes the Secretary to convey all right, title, and U.S. interest in the U.S.S. GLACIER (formerly of the National Defense Reserve Fleet) to the Glacier Society, Inc., Bridgeport, Connecticut.

predicted_summary: Country of Origin Label Amendment Act of 2003 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to require labeling of meat produced from cattle produced from beef, lamb, and pork. (Sec. 281) Amends title D (Farm-raised Fish) to include an item described in subparagraph (A) if the item is an ingredient in a processed food item. Makes exceptions for: (1) processed food items; (2) farm-raised fish; (3) fish; and (4) seafood.Permits the use of the term "perishable agricultural commodity" to include a retailer or food wholesaler who provides ready-to-eat food to consumers.Requires a retailer to notify consumers at the final point of sale of covered commodities of its country of origin if the covered commodity is exclusively from an animal exclusively born, raised, and slaughtered in the United States.Defines wild fish and farm-raised fish as products produced in the United States.Authorizes the Secretary to use existing records to verify compliance with this Act.Directs the Secretary to carry out a program that provides for the self-certification by producers of covered commodities.Prohibits a retailer or other person from requiring, as a condition of the purchase of beef, lamb, or pork or of live cattle, hogs, or sheep from a producer or packer, that the producer indemnifies the retailer from any liability arising from a violation of this Act.Directs the Secretary to determine whether a covered commodity is adulterated or misbranded and to impose a civil penalty on the retailer for failing to comply with such requirements.Directs the Secretary to enter into partnerships with States with enforcement infrastructure to assist in the administration of this subtitle.
summary: Country of Origin Labeling Amendment Act of 2003 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to revise country of origin labeling provisions, including: (1) specifying the model certification of origin program; (2) specifying producer protections; (3) reducing maximum retailer fines; (4) prohibiting treatment of country of origin violations as adulteration or misbranding; and (5) extending the implementing guideline deadline.

predicted_summary: Homeowner Empowerment Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend the authority of the Congress to lay and collect taxes on income from qualified retirement plans used for mortgage payments; and (2) exclude certain distributions from gross income of such plan owners to the extent that such distribution exceeds $5,000.Qualified Mortgage Distributions - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) prohibit distributions from individuals receiving a qualified mortgage to the extent that such distributions exceed the minimum payment due under the terms of the mortgage.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make the aggregate amount of contributions to an individual retirement plan equal to the amount distributions paid to such plan holders; and (2) require such contributions to be includible in the gross income of the taxpayer for the 12-year period in which such plan ends in lieu of such taxable year.(Sec. 3) Amends the Federal mortgage distribution code to: (1) extend the distribution period through December 31, 2017, to allow such distribution to be distributed through a third-party distribution provider (DPSC) at the date on which such distribution is made, and to extend such distribution through a specified time frame.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to distribute distributions to such entities as follows: (1) to individuals and corporations; and (2) to persons under the age of 18 who have made distributions after the date of enactment of this Act.
summary: Homeowner Empowerment Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) exclude from gross income distributions from individual retirement plans and other qualified retirement plans for payments on the mortgage of a taxpayer's principal residence; (2) require repayments of amounts distributed from such retirement plans over a 12-year period; and (3) waive the 10% penalty on premature distributions from retirement plans for distributions used to pay a mortgage.
